content: hey guys welcome back to Blackmagic
craft as a big huge milestone for this channel fast approaches I know crazy
right I've been doing a lot of thinking a lot of introspection about this
channel and this hobby and I've been thinking about what it must be like for
a lot of these new viewers to come into the channel and maybe into this hobby
now what is that first impression of the hobby like for them versus those that
have seen this channel and my skills and this hobby grow slowly over time if you
are unfamiliar with this hobby and you were to tune in to this channel right
now today for the first time and watch a video like my heggs Hut build or maybe
painting a miniature like the shipwreck revenant I would say it could appear as
a very intimidating thing doing something like that yourself could seem
like a monumental task and understandably so it's really easy to
look at me making something like that or to look at projects built by various
veteran crafters in groups online like the tabletop crafters guild and think
that we are experts in our field doing something that you could never ever do
but that thought process is wrong it's it's really really flawed don't think
like that artisans in any field are not magically born with the abilities that
they use they learn them over time through practice and through failure
they keep doing it they keep learning they keep failing until they get good at
it and this is true of every artisan including myself it wasn't that long ago
that I had never played Dungeons and Dragons never done any sort of tabletop
gaming or building or crafting in the summer of 2015 a friend decided that she
wanted to try out playing done and Dragons and I agreed to join on as a
player and you right off the bat that I probably would struggle with just doing
a pure theater of the mind role play I knew that I would need some visual aids
to make me feel more comfortable in that setting
so we tried out our first couple games and me as a player we awkwardly played
two or three games and I knew immediately that I was hooked I knew
that I had found my new hobby it didn't take long for the gears to start turning
and for me to decide that I wanted to run my own game I want it to be a DM I
wanted to create my own world my own setting and I wanted to use all of these
cool things that I had seen online props terrain miniatures I was super excited
at the time my outside of day job hobby passion side hustle thing was music I
was an electronic music producer but I recently had a new baby and the life of
a musician was not conducive to being a new father I could no longer make a ton
of noise in the home studio till 2:00 in the morning because I had a newborn baby
that I was just always hoping and praying would just fall asleep and stay
asleep and I couldn't really leave home to travel and play shows so the idea of
this new hobby of playing tabletop gaming and crafting was perfectly timed
it was the perfect hobby at the perfect time it would keep me at home it was
quiet and I could pick it up and put it down as I saw fit so I established a
group of players and I set to work preparing for my first game I created a
storyline my own world my own setting all this stuff and I on my first game
knew I wanted to use terrain I had seen some videos from at that time the dm's
craft who was one of the pioneers of doing this sort of thing on YouTube and
I had watched some videos from what at the time was called drunk ins and
Dragons now known as rune hammer with a bit of an idea of the types of things
you could make and what you could make them out of I set to work
building my first props for my first game my first encounter of my first
session was to take place in a swamp so I made some swap boards my background
with my day job as a contractor did make me familiar with a bunch of different
building materials so I grabbed something that I was familiar with and
that was insulation foam XPS foam that's why I started with it it was something
that I knew about that I had used and had access to you I also had access to a
blowtorch because I did a lot of plumbing work so I grabbed some foam
took it outside with my blowtorch and started sculpting these swamp boards I
gave them a very simple paint job glued some moss and stuff to it to look like
vegetation and then I said huh why not try these water effects that I've seen
in pictures went to Michael's got some two-part resin and poured water effects
I'd never done any of this before and while I was comfortable with some of the
materials I was using I certainly had never done anything like poured resin or
water but I did it anyway why why did I jump headfirst into kind of complicated
and materials because I firmly believe that you learn the most like trying the
most the more you try the more you learn the more you try the more you probably
fail and the more you fail the more you learn so I just just went for it I also
at this time crafted my very first building a little rotten decrepid Chapel
that would be placed in the middle of the swamp I made it out of cardboard and
just painted it and that was it and it kind of sucked but I had so much fun
doing it I knew while building that little house that I really had found my
calling so to speak didn't matter that it looked kind of crappy it looked like
a million bucks to me and I enjoyed the process so much that I just kept going
with it and I proceeded to keep building and building different
things and getting more immersed in the hobby at the time miniature painting
still seemed like too big of an expense and a little bit intimidating so I made
paper minis I made everything that I needed or wanted for my games using
whatever I had on hand to the best of my abilities and with each project I kept
getting a little bit better the funny thing is that about three months in
after making the first swamp board in chapel I decided to start this channel
which is kind of hilarious in retrospect that meet a guy who had just started
this hobby and really knew very little about it and also knew nothing about
video making nothing about YouTube decided to make a channel dedicated to
this hobby like I I'm not sure why he did that I'm glad I did but I jumped in
headfirst not knowing very much you can go back and you can watch those old
videos and you can see that I didn't really know what I was doing my project
for simple my videos much like the projects were awkward but they were full
of raw determination if you actually go back and watch my videos in order you
can see me quite literally learning this craft along with learning how to do
YouTube and videos you can see me going from simple projects to more complicated
I still today don't consider myself an expert at either terrain building or
video making or YouTube but I think that's kind of why this channel has
worked because I'm just a guy who is willing to learn and willing to try
things and willing to fail and share my journey with all of you I used to really
really suck at this and in some regards I kind of still do but I never let that
stop me and it shouldn't stop you either the only way to get good at something
anything is to just do it do it over and over and over again fail fail fail try
things learn and eventually you'll get good at it I don't
here what the art form is if you do it enough you will get good at it when it
comes to tabletop gaming terrain you don't have to be good at it for it to be
effective and to work a lot of the best builds that I've seen were technically
pretty poorly executed not using a great amount of skill or ability but the idea
was so good so solid that it really worked and the end goal here for me and
probably for many of you is to make things for your game to improve the
gameplay not just to make nice things that look really good and sit on a shelf
or impress people on the internet they serve a purpose and they don't have to
be that amazing to serve that purpose so if you're new here
welcome don't be intimidated by some of the things I might be doing on this
channel you too can do them you might just have to start with some simpler
projects go back to the early days of the videos build some simple things like
some tiles or some pillars or some dungeon stackers and see if you enjoy
the Hobby because if you make those projects and you enjoy doing them that
enjoyment is all you need to hold your interest long enough to get better at it
if you don't like it well you don't like it but if you do just keep doing it and
eventually you'll get good and then maybe eventually you can think about
getting more serious in the Hobby and investing more in tools and supplies but
you don't have to the start just get some cardboard or some foam and a knife
a glue gun and go to town and build that's really all I wanted to say this
week a wishy-washy message about trying and failing and don't be intimidated by
this hobby just just start making stuff I hope you found this video entertaining
may be informative and most of all as usual inspiring because that's my main
goal with every video I make if you liked this video hit that like button if
you're into that sort of thing and let me know in the comments section below
I'd really to hear your story your journey as a
crafter or Terrain maker or DM whatever so let me know in the comments section
I'd love to read how this experience has been for you going from a new person
who's never done it before to wherever you're at today of course if you liked
this video and you'd like these videos that I make every week consider
supporting Blackmagic crafts on patreon it's through the support of those people
that I'm able to dedicate all my time and effort into making these videos and
also I'd love to have you as the newest member of the black magic crafts
fellowship I'm getting on that group it is full of wonderful people who range in
ability and experience they and I are there to help you on your own journey
join up join the group ask your question share your work get feedback it's a
really wonderful place I promise that's it for this week guys see you next week
Cheers
you
